metadata.title: Poly-cytosine DNA as a High-Affinity Ligand for Inorganic Nanomaterials

sections.text:
DNA-functionalized nanomaterials show promise for making biosensors and switches,[1] drug delivery vehicles,[2] and stimuli-responsive materials.[3] A critical step is to attach DNA to nanoparticles while still retaining its hybridization activity. Thiol and amino-modified DNAs form stable conjugates on gold and carboxyl-terminated surfaces, respectively. Many other materials are however more challenging for covalent DNA conjugation, such as metal oxides and dichalcogenides. For certain applications, simple adsorption of DNA might be sufficient. For example, poly-adenine (polyA) is a popular anchor for gold nanoparticles (AuNPs)[4–9] and graphene oxide (GO).[10]
To improve adsorption, aptamers were also selected against nanomaterials. For example, GT repeats were found to be optimal for single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs).[11] A poly-thymine (T30) DNA was claimed to be an aptamer for ZnO.[12] Inorganic surfaces usually have periodic structures comparable with the length scale of DNA nucleotides (that is, about 0.3 nm). This may explain
why the above aptamers are made of simple repeating sequences.[11, 12] Therefore, instead of performing aptamer selections, DNA homopolymers might be a good starting point for surface-binding DNA. Herein, we communicate a quite surprising yet useful finding that poly-cytosine (polyC) DNA binds strongly to many common inorganic surfaces.
To gain a comprehensive understanding, we tested four types of nanomaterials each with two examples, including nanocarbons (GO and SWNTs), metal dichalcogenides (MoS2 and WS2), metal oxides (Fe3O4 and ZnO), and metals (AuNPs and AgNPs). Some TEM images are shown in Figure 1A–D, while the rest are in the Supporting Information, Figure S1. Since DNA is a polyanion and electrostatic
interaction is likely to be important, their z-potential was measured (Figure 1 E). Only ZnO was positively charged, while the rest were negative. Finally, all these materials quench adsorbed fluorophores,[13–16] allowing convenient assays for following DNA adsorption/desorption.
To compare DNA adsorption affinity, we started with the four carboxyfluorescein (FAM)-labeled 15-mer homo-DNA. GO is used as an example to illustrate our experiment. First, the four FAM-labeled probes were each adsorbed on GO, resulting in quenched fluorescence.[14] Then, the four nonlabeled 15-mer homo-DNAs were added to hybridize with or displace the adsorbed probes (Figure 1F), which was accompanied with fluorescence enhancement. The kinetics of desorption from GO for the four probes are shown in Figure 2A–D. A few interesting observations were made. First, adding C15 induced the highest probe desorption in all

the samples (for example, the green lines in Figure 2A–D are the highest). A15 induced the second highest probe desorption, except when FAM-C15 was adsorbed as a probe. In that case, G15 had a slightly higher final signal (Figure 2C) attributable to the formation of the G15/C15 duplex. The percentage of desorption after 1 h is given in Figure 2E. Second, when FAM-C15 was adsorbed as a probe, its desorption was very low except when C15 was added (Figure 2C). We further adsorbed a FAM-24-mer random DNA, and C15 still gave the highest signal (Supporting Information, Figure S2). These indicate that C15 has the highest affinity on GO.
To further confirm our results, we compared desorption of FAM-T15 by adding various concentrations of A15 and C15, where 5 mm A15 desorbed only about 40% of FAM-T15, while 0.5 mm C15 displaced more than 50 % (Supporting Information, Figure S3). Note that A15 can hybridize with FAM-T15, while C15 cannot. C15 producing a greater signal suggests that C15 has a much stronger affinity than A15 on GO. A few controls were performed to ensure our observation was not a DNA concentration artifact (Supporting Information, Figures S4–S6).
The fact that C15 adsorbs on GO stronger than A15 is quite surprising. For single bases, it is well-established that the purines adsorb on graphene more strongly than the pyrimi-
dines.[17] To understand this, we performed a DNA-length dependent study still using FAM-T15 as a probe. Poly-C and poly-A of various lengths were added, and the ratio of desorbed FAM-T15 is plotted (Figure 2F). Indeed, for the 1- mer nucleoside or nucleotide, more desorption by A was observed, while for 5-mer or longer, more desorption was induced by the poly-C, suggesting poly-C relies on intrastrand interactions to afford its high adsorption strength.
Inspired by this, we tested the other seven nanomaterials. Their DNA desorption kinetics are shown in the Supporting Information, Figures S7–S13. Herein we only present the desorption percentage at 1 h. For SWNTs, the same trend as GO was observed (Figure 3A), but with a slower kinetics (Supporting Information, Figure S7), which is consistent with
previous reports.[18, 19] DNA interacts with GO and SWNT via their carboxyl groups and p–p stacking. However, MoS2 and WS2 do not have such groups and they interact with DNA via van der Waals forces.[20] Interestingly, C15 still induced the most desorption on MoS2 and WS2 (Figure 3B,C). In particular, when the FAM-C15 was adsorbed, only C15 induced its desorption, suggesting that C15 can also serve as a stable anchor on them.
We then studied metal oxides. For Fe3O4, C15 still induced the most desorption in each case (Figure 3D). Similar observations were also made with ZnO, the only positively charged material tested (Figure 3E). Our previous work indicated that DNA adsorbs on metal oxides via its phosphate backbone,[21, 22] a mechanism different from the carbons or dichalcogenides.
Finally, barely any desorption occurred on AuNPs and AgNPs, consistent with very strong chemisorption of DNA bases on noble metals (for example, DNA hybridization energy weaker than DNA adsorption energy).[23] On a gold surface, Tarlov, Whitman and co-workers showed that the

adsorption affinity followed A5>C5 G5>T5.[24] Although A15 is likely to be stronger than C15 on AuNPs as well,
[25] C15 is strong enough to also qualify as a high-affinity ligand. As a separate note, G15 may form a G-quadruplex, which needs to be kept in mind when interpreting related data. Poly-G is typically omitted in surface adsorption studies to avoid such complications, but we included it here to have a complete understanding and also because of the special property of poly-C.
To better summarize our data, we added the total desorption of the four FAM-labeled probes by each DNA (Figure 3H). The green bars (desorption by C15) were the highest in each case as expected. The difference between the green bars and the other bars appears to increase when the overall height of the bars also increases. In other words, for surfaces that adsorb DNA more weakly, the relative strength of C15 is more obvious.
To further quantify this, we took the average of the four bars for each material in Figure 3 H as a measure of DNA adsorption affinity (for example, less DNA desorption for a higher affinity surface). We then used the difference of the C15 data (the green bars) and the average of the other three bars as a measure of the poly-C effect. These two factors are plotted in Figure 4A, and a linear correlation was indeed established (R2 = 0.87). This confirms that the C15 DNA is adsorbed more strongly relative to other DNAs when the overall interaction is weak (for example on GO). For very high affinity surfaces, such as AuNPs, the poly-C DNA did not stand out.
C-rich DNAs are prone to form the i-motif in acidic pH, in which C:CH+ base pairs are key building blocks (Figure 4B).[26] A few carbon-based nanomaterials were reported
to induce i-motif even at slightly basic pH, including SWNTs,[27, 28] C60,
[29] and graphene quantum dots.[30] These reports, however, did not touch on adsorption affinity, which is the focus of the current work.
Given that the nanocarbons promote i-motif formation, we also tested the other materials using circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy (Figure 4C). The free human telomeric DNA formed the i-motif at pH 5.5 indicated by the characteristic 290 nm positive peak, but not at pH 7.5. The i-motif was observed at pH 7.5 with GO and SWNT (Figure 4C), consistent with previous reports.[27–30] However, we failed to see the i-motif at pH 7.5 with the other nanomaterials (Figure 4D), indicating that the DNA adsorbed on them as an random coil. As such, the stronger adsorption of poly-C on those materials cannot be attributed to i-motif formation. In fact, for a folded DNA, a lower adsorption affinity would be expected. For example, by folding a DNA into a duplex, an aptamer complex, or a quadruplex, its affinity on GO is decreased.[14, 31] Therefore, it is reasonable that poly-C is not adsorbed as an i-motif on non-carbon surfaces. For carbon surfaces, the increased affinity for the i-motif might be due to special p–p stacking or carboxyl interactions.[27–30]
Carbon-based materials adsorb DNA using p–p stacking and hydrogen bonding.[32,33] WS2 and MoS2 rely on van der Waals forces.[20] Metal oxides interact mainly with DNA phosphate backbone.[15, 21, 34] Noble metals form strong coordination bonds with DNA bases.[35] We believe the reason for poly-C adsorbing more tightly is different for each surface. Finding the exact reason will be a topic of future studies, and it might be related to the highest pKa of cytosine to be protonated more easily.[23] Since many types of nanomaterials are available beyond the ones tested here, it is quite likely that poly-C might not be the best ligand in every case.
Based on the above data, we reason that poly-C DNA can work as an anchor to functionalize these surfaces. While polyA is commonly used for this purpose on AuNPs[4–9] and GO,[10]
our data suggest that poly-C might be even better for nonmetallic surfaces. To test this, we designed two diblock DNAs containing a poly-C or poly-A block for surface anchoring and the other block for hybridization (Figure 5A). The bare GO surface adsorbed FAM-labeled probes efficiently, but it had no sequence selectivity (Figure 5B, blue and green lines). With the poly-A anchor, the target (FAM-cDNA) slowly hybridized, while the non-target (FAM-non-cDNA) remained in solution. This indicates that the poly-A containing DNA blocked the GO surface and supported specific hybridization. Interestingly, the poly-C anchored DNA allowed faster hybridization with the cDNA, but not the non-cDNA (Figure 5C). To quantify specific hybridization, we compared the difference between the red and black traces in Figure 5B and C at 60 min (the length of the blue arrows in Figure 5B,C). In this case, the amount of DNA that underwent specific hybridization doubled with the poly-C anchor than that with the poly-A. We further challenged the system with homo-DNA, surfactants, polymers, proteins, and serum (each was added together with the FAM-labeled DNA probes), and plotted the fraction of DNA that underwent specific hybridization (Figure 5D). In most cases, the poly-A anchored system could barely distinguish the target from non-

These are not the final page numbers!
target (for example the yellow bars are close to zero), especially with interfering DNA and surfactants. This is most likely due to non-specific DNA displacement. The poly-C still retained its specific hybridization ability in all the cases. Therefore, the advantage of using poly-C is even more pronounced in complex matrix.
In summary, we have discovered that poly-C DNA has a much stronger affinity than other DNA homopolymers for nanocarbons, transition-metal dichalcogenides, and metal oxides. Its high affinity is not related to the i-motif, except for the carbon materials. Non-covalent adsorption of DNA has been most extensively performed on AuNPs. This study allows simple and cost-effective non-covalent DNA functionalization of many other important materials. While it is unlikely to replace covalent conjugation, physisorption is useful for controlling DNA density,[5] DNA-directed assembly,[36] nanoparticle growth,[37, 38] making mono-functionalized particles,[39,40] and multiplexed detection and delivery.[41]
Many of these have been demonstrated with AuNPs, and using poly-C can extend such methods to other materials. Poly-C DNA also provides a reference for aptamers selected against surfaces. Newly selected aptamers should be better than poly-C DNA in terms of affinity. Finally, it provides an interesting system to study biointerface chemistry.

Poly-cytosine DNA as a High-Affinity Ligand for Inorganic Nanomaterials
Straight-C student : Poly-cytosine (poly-C) DNA adsorbs tighter than other DNA homopolymers (such as poly-A) on nanocarbons, metal oxides, and transition-metal dichalcogenides, allowing poly-C to be used as a general anchor on these surfaces for their functionalization, especially in the presence of competing proteins, nucleic acids, and surfactants. Compared to other homo-DNA sequences, poly-C DNA has the highest affinity for the first three types of materials. Using a diblock DNA containing a poly-C block to attach to surfaces, the target DNA was successfully hybridized to the other block on graphene oxide more efficiently than that containing a typical poly-A block, especially in the presence of non-specific background DNA, proteins, or surfactants. Our previous work indicated that DNA adsorbs on metal oxides via its phosphate backbone, 22] a mechanism different from the carbons or dichalcogenides. Finally, barely any desorption occurred on AuNPs and AgNPs, consistent with very strong chemisorption of DNA bases on noble metals (for example, DNA hybridization energy weaker than DNA adsorption energy). Although A15 is likely to be stronger than C15 on AuNPs as well, [25] C15 is strong enough to also qualify as a high-affinity ligand. As a separate note, G15 may form a G-quadruplex, which needs to be kept in mind when interpreting related data. Poly-G is typically omitted in surface adsorption studies to avoid such complications, but we included it here to have a complete understanding and also because of the special property of poly-C. To better summarize our data, we added the total desorption of the four FAM-labeled probes by each DNA (Figure 3H). The green bars (desorption by C15) were the highest in each case as expected. The difference between the green bars and the other bars appears to increase when the overall height of the bars also increases. In other words, for surfaces that adsorb DNA more weakly, the relative strength of C15 is more obvious. To further quantify this, we took the average of the four bars for each material in Figure 3 H as a measure of DNA adsorption affinity (for example, less DNA desorption for a higher affinity surface). We then used the difference of the C15 data (the green bars) and the average of the other three bars as a measure of the poly-C effect. These two factors are plotted in Figure 4A, and a linear correlation was indeed established (R = 0.87). This confirms that the C15 DNA is adsorbed more strongly relative to other DNAs when the overall interaction is weak (for example on GO). For very high affinity surfaces, such as AuNPs, the poly-C DNA did not stand out. C-rich DNAs are prone to form the i-motif in acidic pH, in which C:CH base pairs are key building blocks (Figure 4B). A few carbon-based nanomaterials were reported to induce i-motif even at slightly basic pH, including SWNTs, 28] C60, [29] and graphene quantum dots. These reports, however, did not touch on adsorption affinity, which is the focus of the current work. Given that the nanocarbons promote i-motif formation, we also tested the other materials using circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy (Figure 4C). The free human telomeric DNA formed the i-motif at pH 5.5 indicated by the characteristic 290 nm positive peak, but not at pH 7.5. The i-motif was observed at pH 7.5 with GO and SWNT (Figure 4C), consistent with previous reports. However, we failed to see the i-motif at pH 7.5 with the other nanomaterials (Figure 4D), indicating that the DNA adsorbed on them as an random coil. As such, the stronger adsorption of poly-C on those materials cannot be attributed to i-motif formation. In fact, for a folded DNA, a lower adsorption affinity would be expected. For example, by folding a DNA into a duplex, an aptamer complex, or a quadruplex, its affinity on GO is decreased. 31] Therefore, it is reasonable that poly-C is not adsorbed as an i-motif on non-carbon surfaces. For carbon surfaces, the increased affinity for the i-motif might be due to special p–p stacking or carboxyl interactions. Carbon-based materials adsorb DNA using p–p stacking and hydrogen bonding. WS2 and MoS2 rely on van der Waals forces. Metal oxides interact mainly with DNA phosphate backbone. 21, 34] Noble metals form strong coordination bonds with DNA bases. We believe the reason for poly-C adsorbing more tightly is different for each surface. Finding the exact reason will be a topic of future studies, and it might be related to the highest pKa of cytosine to be protonated more easily. Since many types of nanomaterials are available beyond the ones tested here, it is quite likely that poly-C might not be the best ligand in every case. Based on the above data, we reason that poly-C DNA can work as an anchor to functionalize these surfaces. While polyA is commonly used for this purpose on AuNPs and GO, our data suggest that poly-C might be even better for nonmetallic surfaces. To test this, we designed two diblock DNAs containing a poly-C or poly-A block for surface anchoring and the other block for hybridization (Figure 5A). The bare GO surface adsorbed FAM-labeled probes efficiently, but it had no sequence selectivity (Figure 5B, blue and green lines). With the poly-A anchor, the target (FAM-cDNA) slowly hybridized, while the non-target (FAM-non-cDNA) remained in solution. This indicates that the poly-A containing DNA blocked the GO surface and supported specific hybridization. Interestingly, the poly-C anchored DNA allowed faster hybridization with the cDNA, but not the non-cDNA (Figure 5C). To quantify specific hybridization, we compared the difference between the red and black traces in Figure 5B and C at 60 min (the length of the blue arrows in Figure 5B,C). In this case, the amount of DNA that underwent specific hybridization doubled with the poly-C anchor than that with the poly-A. We further challenged the system with homo-DNA, surfactants, polymers, proteins, and serum (each was added together with the FAM-labeled DNA probes), and plotted the fraction of DNA that underwent specific hybridization (Figure 5D). Therefore, the advantage of using poly-C is even more pronounced in complex matrix. In summary, we have discovered that poly-C DNA has a much stronger affinity than other DNA homopolymers for nanocarbons, transition-metal dichalcogenides, and metal oxides. Its high affinity is not related to the i-motif, except for the carbon materials. Non-covalent adsorption of DNA has been most extensively performed on AuNPs. This study allows simple and cost-effective non-covalent DNA functionalization of many other important materials. While it is unlikely to replace covalent conjugation, physisorption is useful for controlling DNA density, DNA-directed assembly, nanoparticle growth, 38] making mono-functionalized particles, and multiplexed detection and delivery. Many of these have been demonstrated with AuNPs, and using poly-C can extend such methods to other materials. Poly-C DNA also provides a reference for aptamers selected against surfaces. Newly selected aptamers should be better than poly-C DNA in terms of affinity. Finally, it provides an interesting system to study biointerface chemistry.
